text:
PAXTON HEHMEYER: I want
to introduce Dr. Chou. So he has a long and
illustrious career

before he got into
cloud computing. But the part I'll focus on is
when he started really on--

when that was just
getting started in 1999, when you were brought back to
Oracle to launch and run Oracle

On Demand. And out of that experience,
as I understand, you wrote this book in 2004,
called The End of Software.

And in that book,
It's really one of the first works that
talks about software

as a service, which of course
is now a household term today. And in fact in that,
you mentioned three,

at then, startups that
are now also businesses that just about everyone knows. So VMware, NetSuite,
and Salesforce.

Shortly after you
wrote that book, you launched the class we'll be
talking about today, the cloud

computing class in 2005. And so right on
the heels of that. And as we were talking about--
shortly after that, in 2006,

I think just six months after
that class probably debuted, Amazon launched some of the
real inaugural cloud services--

infrastructure cloud services. So S3 and I think EC2, so the
computing and storage service. TIMOTHY CHOU: I thought
you weren't technical.

PAXTON HEHMEYER: What? TIMOTHY CHOU: I thought
you weren't technical. PAXTON HEHMEYER: Well,
I'm not technical. I have to do a little
bit of research.

Really, this class is embedded--
and your work is really-- you were at the forefront of
it, and thinking about, writing

about as a practitioner and
visionary for cloud computing. And obviously, you've done
a lot of things since then.

And in fact, I
should note you were teaching with SCPD far before
the cloud computing seminar. So you were teaching I
believe computer architecture

in the electrical
engineering department. So you have a long
history there as well.

Maybe that wasn't the cloud,
but teaching online as well. And then most recently, so
there's a long history here.

But in 2020, you
launched a company that's using the edge
cloud to really transform

pediatric care. And hopefully, we can
hear a little bit more about that experience. So we're really excited
to have you here today.

The opportunity to
talk about the class and use that as an
opportunity also to think about the cloud more generally.

So I think, for those
in the audience who are like me,
non-technical, it would be great to get a
definition to cloud.

Because I think often, we just-- I just think of as the
internet until you really dig down into it. And I know they're
not synonymous.

So what is the cloud? TIMOTHY CHOU: Yeah,
well, first of all, Pax,

Thanks for having me. Thanks for doing this. This class is, I think,
very unique in the world.

And so getting the
word out for both kids that are here at Stanford as
well as the wider communities.

Thank you for doing that. So what is the cloud? I mean, fundamentally,
if you start

to think about it
in a different way, you would go that what
the cloud is is really

a supplier who builds
software like an application

or maybe builds
hardware, like a server, says rather than you have to
manage the security of it,

the availability,
the performance, the change in that
software, which is where we all came from.

We used to have to do that. Why don't I do that for you? So I'll do that for
you as Salesforce

for CRM applications. I'll do that for you
for storage and compute.

That's what Amazon is doing. So fundamentally, it's a shift
from the old world where--

and in corporate America, I
have whole teams of people having to do this work to
manage the infrastructure,

manage the applications,
the suppliers now. And obviously, the ability for
a network which we have today

to perform was key to
making all this possible, but that clearly had
happened by, let's

call it the dawn of this, which
is really late '99 early 2000. So the other point to make
is that there's two aspects.

One is what I said,
which is, it's about the supplier doing that.

The second part is really
the economic advantage of doing that.

Because if you think about
it, in the old world, if I sent you a piece of
software, well, the way you manage it, and
the way I manage it,

and the way somebody
else manage it, it might be
completely different. And by the way, done by humans.

But if I standardize,
if I say no, I'm just going to do it
for this piece of software.

And I'm going to upgrade it
on Tuesdays at 2 o'clock, or whatever. Then I can progressively
standardize repeat

and automate the process. Where if I automate
it, then all that labor

that used to be used to
go manage this technology, these applications,
this infrastructure,

I can replace with
computers, which by the way are a hell of a lot cheaper. They operate pretty much
flawlessly compared to humans.

And therefore, in a
great sense, they're actually more secure than
the world we have come from. And that economic shift
is the other big thing

that happened-- not only was
technology made available, but also the economics. So it really started, as
you already pointed out,

early on with applications. That's what we did at Oracle. We tried to deliver
the Oracle ERP,
CRM applications as a service. Obviously Salesforce with CRM.

NetSuite with ERP. All started to do this
in applications first.

And then Amazon really
led the game over in infrastructure by saying,
no, not just applications,

but compute and storage. And the economic thing they
did, the business model shift

they made, which was huge
was-- oh, by the way, you can have this
computer for an hour.

And then I'll give-- you
can give it back to me. PAXTON HEHMEYER: So the resource
is just much more flexible. TIMOTHY CHOU: Enormously
more flexible, right?

And so it removed
me having to do any of this, which is why
every startup on the planet uses somebody's
cloud infrastructure.

Why do I want to go manage this? As well as the
economic advantage of being able to do this.

PAXTON HEHMEYER: Yeah, one
of the interesting points-- so I didn't mention
in the my bio of you

is that you also have a trilogy
of books on cloud computing that came out in 2015,
somewhere around there.

And in it, what was really
interesting going through it, is how much you emphasize
that business case.

And one thing that I had no
idea that was very interesting is you were saying, when you
buy software, that's not where

the cost is going to come in. So you were saying-- I think the number you quoted,
and I could be totally wrong, but it's like four times the
cost of the software cost.

You will be spending
annually to maintain it if you're maintaining it on
premises, which blew my mind.

TIMOTHY CHOU: Good memory. Good memory. PAXTON HEHMEYER: Yeah. That's so-- TIMOTHY CHOU: It's enormous. PAXTON HEHMEYER: So that's
the business change,

the economic change? TIMOTHY CHOU:
Absolutely, absolutely. PAXTON HEHMEYER: And I
think you also mentioned,

as you mentioned now, the
big innovation that Amazon introduced was, again, not
necessarily the technical side,

though there were obviously
technical challenges that they had to address, but
was the business model. And so if things got
started in the early 2000s

in terms of applications, in
terms of the infrastructure, moving to the cloud,
what's on the horizon now?

What have been the interesting
developments, especially coming off of a few
years where many of us

were really living in the cloud,
in terms of everything we were doing was being held online?

TIMOTHY CHOU: Yeah,
so let me just highlight a couple of things. And I like to split
between infrastructure

and applications. Think about this. So on the infrastructure
side, I mean Amazon's continued to innovate.

I mean, the number of
services on top of the EC2 S3 is immense. It's in the hundreds, right?

And I think one of the areas
they have been particularly interested in is-- part of everybody's
conversation is the world of AI.

And in particular,
how does AI really begin to help programmers--

it's a weird thing to think
about taking programmers out of the loop. And how do I use AI to do that.

They're also helping people
start to learn about this. So there's a project they have
out there called DeepRacer.

People, take a look at it. It's really you
get to go program an autonomous virtual car.

To try to begin-- because I think we do,
and obviously Stanford's at the forefront of this. But across the world,
a lack of understanding

of what capabilities this
type of technology has which really is formed from the
basics of cloud computing.

If you spent any time in
the world of deep learning, you know that to get more
accurate predictions, more

accurate-- more accuracy,
you need two things. You need more data. And you need more compute.

Well, guess what? Getting more and more compute
is part of what cloud. Infrastructure. So Amazon is pushing that.

I'll highlight another
company, Teradata. In fact, I was just-- I'm on the board. We just did a New York Stock
Exchange event two days ago.

And they've just introduced, at
the database level, the ability to have not only data lakes
but data warehouses, what

some people call lake houses,
as infrastructure as a service to now start to provide higher
level services, not just

the compute and
storage, but the ability to do analytics on structured
and unstructured data.

So that's a step many people
have made because analytics is huge in everybody's business.

Another one just to highlight. One of the things
I've been able to do is I'm part of the Alchemist
Accelerator, which is actually

a little bit of a Stanford spin
out, because Ravi and I are all part of the community.

But we had a number
of great stories. Just to highlight one,
there's a company out there called Yotascale, which
is very early on at Alchemist.

And what they're
endeavoring to do is to help people manage
the cost because--

the good news is, it's
easy to get this stuff. The bad news is, from the
CFO's perspective is, well Pax,

do you really need
that instance? So Yotascale's using
technology to help do cost management of
what is a burgeoning

amount of resource being used
by people like Hulu, or Disney, or whatever.

And it has an interesting
implication on sustainability. Because if you think about
it, in an information age,

the smokestack is the computers. They're generating
all the carbon.

So not only as managing
efficiency cost-wise but also from a carbon perspective.

So that's, I'll
say, a couple little highlights of what's cool
on the infrastructure side.

If you move over
to applications, I'll say, increasingly,
companies that historically

have operated on
premises have moved to delivering all their
applications as a cloud

service. I'll highlight one, Blackbaud,
which many people probably don't know. But they are a company that's
dedicated to building cloud

applications for social good. Their customers are people
like Save the Children.

I think Stanford's a customer
because they started out really in helping people
do fundraising.

They pretty much move
their entire stack. In fact, I think right now,
like 2% of their customers

operate in on premises world. The rest of it is operating
in the cloud world using their applications as
a cloud service and Azure

and Amazon as the
infrastructure. And they're about to
hit a billion dollars.

In fact, the plan is
next year, they'll be a billion dollars
as a business.

I'll give you another one. There's an interesting
company, again, an Alchemist Accelerator
company called Oomnitza.

Oomnitza has seen this
explosion in the use

of whether it's
laptops, cell phones, cloud infrastructure
applications in the enterprise.

And is now saying, hey, Mr
or Ms CIO, why don't you

have an application.
so you can manage that incredibly complex-- and remember, these
days that technology

is now in people's houses. And how do I manage
the security? How do I manage
offboarding an employee?

All the different things I
have to think about doing, how do I use computers
to go do that?

And that's just an
example of there's so many at this stage you know
what I call application cloud

services spurred by the
availability of infrastructure cloud services.

PAXTON HEHMEYER: That's
really interesting. We're going to dive into
the class a little bit, but just a couple
follow-up quick.

On the infrastructure side,
do you see-- so again, when I-- and this is the
non-technical layperson.

I think of Amazon,
Microsoft, and Google as the big infrastructure
side providers.

You mentioned AI. Is that creating--
I've also heard that there is-- that's opening
up a space for more niche

providers of those services
that are tailored specifically towards AI. Is that what you're
saying with the analytics?

There's an opportunity--
competition is entering in providing those
niche storage and compute

services that are maybe
around specific functions, is that a fair statement? And if so, can you
elaborate on that?

are all increasingly
providing more capabilities to deliver the ability to train
AI algorithms where there's

a lot of compute required. In fact, as some
people are aware of, there are specialized
hunks of hardware

being built by guys like Google
to go do this sort of thing. So it is not lost on them either
that this is not interesting.

I think in any industry, as
you get bigger and bigger, there is the chance
for specialization.

So it is entirely
possible-- and this could be specialization by location.

Because one of the things
that the big cloud-- infrastructure
cloud providers is, really, they operate out of
10 data centers in the world,

not 100, not 1,000. There are reasons why
it might be better to be closer to the
source of the information,

from communication
point of view. But also increasingly, I think
in the world we're living in,

there's increasingly
walls going up that-- because I've been working
a lot in health care,

there's increasingly walls
going up even between Europe and the United States. We're not sharing.

So this calls into
question, yes, we're going to have to start to move
the infrastructure perhaps

to specialized players, perhaps
to different kinds of cloud service players as well.

PAXTON HEHMEYER: That's
really interesting. So I mean, when you
think of the cloud, you think it just exists
out there in the cloud.

But in fact, it has
this infrastructure. And that it sounds
like that might even become more important in
some senses as the world,

the political world changes. TIMOTHY CHOU: Yes, yes. PAXTON HEHMEYER: Great,
well, so with that,

I want to learn
more of what we're going to be doing this year
in the cloud computing class.

So back in 2005,
why did you start CS309A is the Stanford number,
the Cloud Computing Seminar?

What compelled you to do that? Yeah, could you tell us
a little bit about that? TIMOTHY CHOU: Yeah, so as
you indicated in the opening

comments, I taught core computer
architecture as a hobby.

I'd leave work, come
to campus, teach class. It was fun. PAXTON HEHMEYER: I just-- I had taught a graduate
seminar class as a hobby.

TIMOTHY CHOU: Yeah, well, I
could tell you the whole story about how that happened. But anyway, I was doing that.

And so I taught for 15 years. Actually every other
quarter, core curriculum,

what in those days was called
CS110 and W181 for old timers.

And so there came a day where
I actually had to fly to Bali

to do a sales kickoff meeting
and get back in 36 hours to teach class.

And I was going, this is getting
to be a little ridiculous. So I gave myself a sabbatical,
a leave of absence.

So as you said, I was at Oracle. And I decided, at some
point, I was going to leave.

And so I was hanging
around campus. And for those of you
guys in computer science who know Clare
Steger, Clare and I

know each other for lots
of years, obviously. And so Clare is like, well, why
don't you come back and teach?

I was like that's a lot of work. So well, you could
do a seminar class.

And so I started thinking
about the fact that-- because I was on campus some
of the time, people would say,

where's the computer
science department? And over time, you go, well,
you point to the gates building.

But I was starting to
think about it, well, why do I point to
the gates building? Why am I not pointing to the
geology, and the physics,

and the sociology, and
the psychology buildings? Why do I not think that, right?

And so it made me think
a lot about, well, how is it that we get the
wider population are students

in medicine, law,
the liberal arts to really begin to appreciate
what this technology could do

to reshape any of these areas. And so obviously, because I've
been around here for a while,

I knew a lot of people. And I said, well, why
don't I put together a class where I do the
first and last lecture?

And by the way, they're
probably pretty identical-- back to not working too hard. And in between, I would
have eight guest lectures.

And all my guest lectures would
be CEOs of public companies to come and tell their
story in essence.

Which obviously, I'm
not trying to get down to how do you provision
an EC2 instance.

But why and how were
they going to-- were they using this technology
to begin to bring a wider

group of people into this? So we very much campaigned. In fact, I just sent a bunch
of emails out to my friends

in the law school. We have had a good number
of kids out of law school because I say, look, the
intersection between the law

and computer science,
software, AI is onus. And I would claim we
can easily, today,

see how stupid the laws
are because nobody really understands the technology. So is it going to be that
we teach all of our computer

science kids about the law or
do we teach the law students?

Maybe not, I don't care if you
could be a Python programmer, but can you understand
the concepts,

and why the
economics, et cetera. So that we make more informed
decisions in the law,

in medicine, in the liberal
arts across the board. And that was my mission. And over time, I learned
that people were not

offended to be asked to deliver
a guest lecture at Stanford. So some of the kids
now call the class,

people Tim wants to listen to. PAXTON HEHMEYER: And
so that's interesting. So it's not primarily--

one thing that is interesting
in terms of our portfolio is we have a lot of seminars,
but they're highly technical.

So it's researchers in AI coming
in and talking about the latest algorithm, or the latest way
to verify a neural network,

or something like that. This is not as technical. This is more focused
on the business

side of a very specific
technology as well. Can you talk a little bit
more about your student body

and what your
students are getting-- what are your computer
science students getting out of it versus what are your
say law or business students

getting out of it? Is it the same thing? I mean, what are they
bringing that's unique or what are they
getting out of it that's unique in the
way this class is?

TIMOTHY CHOU: Yeah, well,
you may appreciate this. One of the things--
I think all the kids-- I call them the kids.

All the kids I
have taken, I think they do get a lot out of it. So what do they get out of it? I think on the one hand,
I have a requirement

to get-- it's a
one credit class. So I have a requirement. One of the requirements
is that they

ask a question because I start
out the class the same way. I go, the mark of
a great student is not measured by what you know
but by the questions you ask.

So I want you to learn
to ask good questions. And so just as practice,
before every lecture shows up,

I have a shared spreadsheet. And there's Pax's name and Pax's
question for Raghu from VMware.

And I think that helps,
because then they get a little bit deeper into,
what the heck does VMware do

or GitLab? I mean, for some people,
they already know, but a lot of people don't. So they begin to develop an
appreciation because I always

tell the lecturers, unless
you're Google or Facebook, nobody knows what you do,
including General Electric

by the way. So I think that gets
them a little deeper into the world, one.

I think the second thing
that I hope they register out of it is that all CEOs are
not college dropouts who

wear hoodies. I mean, it is a vast different
profiles of what you see there.

And their stories are
across the spectrum. In fact, one of
the things I always

do when the lecture shows
up and I say to them, hey,

I want you to tell me a story
which you would not know about you from the internet. PAXTON HEHMEYER: I've
got-- this would be a--

I should have asked
you that question. By the way, now I
feel like I'm being graded if my questions
are good enough.

TIMOTHY CHOU: You're
doing good, Pax. And so just a simple example
Martin Richenhagen, who

was the CEO of AGCO, one of the
largest agricultural equipment manufacturer in
the United States, actually asked his
board if he could

coach the German equestrian
team in the Olympics. Who the heck? Whatever.

We've had George John. This is great. One of the things
I do is every year

I look to see what
companies just went public, along with my kind
of standing list.

And that year Rocket
Fuel had gone public. And so I'm like, OK, by this
time I learned I could just

send email in and say, oh, hi. Their CEO is George John. Hey, George. Would you like to
come and do a lecture?

And so I get a reply back. Oh, yeah, Tim. I'd be interested. PS, I was your student
a few years ago.

And I went, really? So we met. And for those of us who
had taken this class,

one of the things we
would have the students do was build a small
multitasking kernel.

PAXTON HEHMEYER: So
this is for the-- TIMOTHY CHOU: Computer
architecture class, we go back in time.

And George says, yeah. He must have taken the
class in the spring

because he went home
for summer vacation. He was sleeping in. He said, yeah, my mom woke me up
and said, what you're so lazy.

Why are you still sleeping in? And he goes, mom,
you don't understand. I just wrote a
multitasking kernel.

So we've had this range, right,
PhD students from Stanford, people who do requests.

And I think that
helps the kids see the range of what's possible
out there and not imprint

on one particular pattern. And as a result,
we've had quite a few.

I mean, I'll just
hit one that's fun. There's a team out
of the class of 2019

that launched a new
company called Nooks. PAXTON HEHMEYER: Oh, we're-- yeah, we know Nooks. TIMOTHY CHOU: You
should know Nooks.

And that's Daniel and
a bunch of those guys that were in that class who
decided to go do that and build

a very new, we call it
collaboration environment, particularly focused these
days in the sales world.

But that's just an example of
I think whether the class was the reason. But I think I have heard
this from a number of them

that it has inspired
them, pushed them, made them think what was
possible rather than what

I do believe a lot of
people walk into Stanford, particularly, and
think well, shit. If I didn't write a multitasking
kernel when I was 12 years old,

I got no business in this,
which is patently not true. PAXTON HEHMEYER: Yeah, that's
really-- yeah, we know--

I mean, because that must have
launched just before or just during the pandemic. So it was something they were
rolling out in a lot of classes

here as a alternative way to do
office hours, grading, parties,

watch parties. So that's interesting. I didn't realize that start
was a team in your class. That's good to know.

TIMOTHY CHOU: Yeah. PAXTON HEHMEYER:
Well, so what's on-- that's a great segue
because we're talking--

last time you ran this class
was in 2019, was it 2019? TIMOTHY CHOU: Yeah. PAXTON HEHMEYER: I think
one of the last speakers

was the CEO of Zoom at the time. So again, a very
prescient or serendipitous

invitee in this course. It's been on hold for two
years because of the pandemic. Now, it's coming back.

So what's on offer for
the class this year? And has that changed at
all in the last two years

in terms of how you're
thinking about invitations? How did the last
two years influence who you're thinking
about inviting this year?

TIMOTHY CHOU: Yeah, I'll
just to tell a small story since you brought up Eric. Eric Yuan was actually--

I went back and looked. I think it was the last
lecture of that year of '19. And one of the things, just to
make a comment, because I think

a lot of people think about,
oh, well, the reason people do startup, whatever,
start companies is to make millions of
dollars and whatnot.

Which obviously,
Eric's done well. But he talked a lot
about-- he was actually at the original Webex.

And was there for
a lot of years. And he said, the
reason I started Zoom was the customers we
had just were not happy.

And I knew we could
make them happy. And it just fascinating that
motivation resulted in, today,
a noun, a verb, and an adverb. So just a side quick on Eric.

Yeah, so who's coming this year? We always, I think, our
lineups are pretty all-star.

So remember I said,
I wanted to get to law school and et cetera. So I happen to do a talk for
Morgan Lewis, which is actually

the fourth largest
law firm in the world. And by that, I met Jami
McKeon who's their firm chair.

And so I asked Jami
to come and speak. So one of our speakers
this year is actually the chairman of the fourth
largest law firm in the world.

PAXTON HEHMEYER: Now, is that a
departure from your usual list? Is this someone who's not going
to talk about the business--

is not themselves
in a business that's delivering a cloud app or
a cloud infrastructure? TIMOTHY CHOU: True.

And to your question, yes. She's as far off as I've
gotten because they are-- well,

the law does consume
cloud services. But obviously, one of the
things that I invited her for

is because we know that the law,
privacy, et cetera is starting to impact how we use technology,
whether on the consumer side
or on the enterprise side. So that's really her. But over time, I branched out.

I got particularly interested
in the so-called internet of things, which is how I
ended up having the chair of--

excuse me, the CEO of AGCO
which is the fourth largest-- excuse me, one of the
largest agriculture equipment

manufacturers, which by the way,
led to, and just as a teaser,

I have been inviting,
there's a lady who is the CEO of TAFE which
is the largest agriculture

equipment manufacturer in India. And I've had a
deliberate move to try to get CEOs of public
companies who are

women to come and do my class. The list is not enormous. In fact, I had Patti Poppe
a couple of years ago.

She was CEO, CMS Energy, which
is Michigan's energy company. Very interestingly, she
started out her talk--

this is why I talk
about kids learn a lot of different things. She got up there and
said, people ask me

how work-life balance works. I suppose they ask me
that because I'm a woman.

And she goes, I think
it's the wrong question. And she proceeds to go into,
which I have introduced people,

there's a whole Japanese
philosophy called ikigai. And she proceeded to do like
a 10-minute dissertation

on ikigai, which
is extremely cool. She talked a lot about energy. At the end, I was
talking to her.

I said, Patti could you come
to PG&E and help us out?

Well, damned if like
nine months ago, she is the new CEO of PG&E. PAXTON HEHMEYER: Wow, OK, well.

TIMOTHY CHOU: So
anyway, so Jami, which is a little out of scope. On the infrastructure front,
Raghu who is the CEO of VMware.

VMware really is a cornerstone
of what people refer to as private cloud computing.

So it's really cool that
he's able to be here. The other one is Sid
who's the CEO of GitLab.

All the CS kids know
what the hell GitLab is, but Git is really the
major repository for code.

So if you are a
software developer or you're using software, your
software is on their software.

Is it the same? TIMOTHY CHOU: Yeah, so Hub
got bought by Microsoft.

And Lab is a spin-- PAXTON HEHMEYER:
OK, there you go. TIMOTHY CHOU: It's lot
of guys who-- yeah. PAXTON HEHMEYER: OK, so
they are two separate? TIMOTHY CHOU: But it's
in principle the same.

It is providing
similar services. The other interesting
thing about Git, which I'm going to
have Sid talk about

is, they very early
on talked about-- they wanted to build a
decentralized business.

This is prior to COVID. So there is no
corporate headquarters, I mean, from day one,
which is fascinating.

And the things
that they have had to do in order to
